issue.title: Bug: [prefer-nullish-coalescing] unexpected fails on condition with generics variable which can be `null` or `undefined`

labels.name: bug
labels.description: Something isn't working

labels.name: package: eslint-plugin
labels.description: Issues related to @typescript-eslint/eslint-plugin

labels.name: triage
labels.description: Waiting for maintainers to take a look

comment.body:
Yes, I agree with you and that was what I exactly did to solve this. It's the perfect solution to this situation.

But this may have other shortcomings, not easy for serializing, for example. And I personally do not think distinction between `null` and `undefined` is unacceptable, since TypeScript does distinguish them (comparing to `undefined` vs `void`). JSON is another example, `null` and absence is different.

Or, could you report another type of rule violate for this case, or add some options to ignore this, as what the `ignorePrimitives` does? In this way one can prevent the dangerous fix action, especially for these auto-fixers.

issue.title: Enhancement: [ban-ts-comment] Autofix ts-ignore to ts-expect-error depending on options

labels.name: package: eslint-plugin
labels.description: Issues related to @typescript-eslint/eslint-plugin

labels.name: triage
labels.description: Waiting for maintainers to take a look

labels.name: enhancement: plugin rule option
labels.description: New rule option for an existing eslint-plugin rule

issue.body:
### Before You File a Proposal Please Confirm You Have Done The Following...

- [X] I have [searched for related issues](https://github.com/typescript-eslint/typescript-eslint/issues?q=is%3Aissue+label%3A%22enhancement%3A+plugin+rule+option%22) and found none that match my proposal.
- [X] I have searched the [current rule list](https://typescript-eslint.io/rules/#supported-rules) and found no rules that match my proposal.
- [X] I have [read the FAQ](https://typescript-eslint.io/linting/troubleshooting) and my problem is not listed.

### My proposal is suitable for this project

- [X] I believe my proposal would be useful to the broader TypeScript community (meaning it is not a niche proposal).

### Link to the rule's documentation

https://typescript-eslint.io/rules/ban-ts-comment/

### Description

A fairly common use-case for `ban-ts-comment` is to ban @ts-ignore in favor of @ts-expect-error.

However, if developers are unfamiliar with @ts-expect-error, the error message doesn't help them find out about it.

![](https://github.com/typescript-eslint/typescript-eslint/assets/1782266/b94c3cf9-2bb5-4ae2-a8bd-cb9e8a09f3f5)

The error message should recommend switching, and an autofix should be provided. If @ts-expect-error is also banned, the above original error message can be used instead.

I think it would be useful to autofix even if the rule is configured to require descriptions, as it still saves keystrokes. I don't know if autofixes are allowed to adjust code into a "fail" state however.

### Fail

```typescript
// @ts-ignore
```


### Pass

```typescript
// @ts-expect-error
// ^autofix
```


### Additional Info

_No response_

comment.body: I agree that suggestion would be nicer than autofix 😁

issue.title: Enhancement: [ban-ts-comment] Autofix ts-ignore to ts-expect-error depending on options

labels.name: package: eslint-plugin
labels.description: Issues related to @typescript-eslint/eslint-plugin

labels.name: triage
labels.description: Waiting for maintainers to take a look

labels.name: enhancement: plugin rule option
labels.description: New rule option for an existing eslint-plugin rule

issue.body:
### Before You File a Proposal Please Confirm You Have Done The Following...

- [X] I have [searched for related issues](https://github.com/typescript-eslint/typescript-eslint/issues?q=is%3Aissue+label%3A%22enhancement%3A+plugin+rule+option%22) and found none that match my proposal.
- [X] I have searched the [current rule list](https://typescript-eslint.io/rules/#supported-rules) and found no rules that match my proposal.
- [X] I have [read the FAQ](https://typescript-eslint.io/linting/troubleshooting) and my problem is not listed.

### My proposal is suitable for this project

- [X] I believe my proposal would be useful to the broader TypeScript community (meaning it is not a niche proposal).

### Link to the rule's documentation

https://typescript-eslint.io/rules/ban-ts-comment/

### Description

A fairly common use-case for `ban-ts-comment` is to ban @ts-ignore in favor of @ts-expect-error.

However, if developers are unfamiliar with @ts-expect-error, the error message doesn't help them find out about it.

![](https://github.com/typescript-eslint/typescript-eslint/assets/1782266/b94c3cf9-2bb5-4ae2-a8bd-cb9e8a09f3f5)

The error message should recommend switching, and an autofix should be provided. If @ts-expect-error is also banned, the above original error message can be used instead.

I think it would be useful to autofix even if the rule is configured to require descriptions, as it still saves keystrokes. I don't know if autofixes are allowed to adjust code into a "fail" state however.

### Fail

```typescript
// @ts-ignore
```


### Pass

```typescript
// @ts-expect-error
// ^autofix
```


### Additional Info

_No response_

comment.body:
Yeah I don't think it's correct to autofix switch things. IMO it's very rare that you actually need an ignore comment and often (from my experience at scale) people are being lazy. With that in mind being short with the wording can push them to looking for better solutions - the right solutions.

For power users though the wording definitely is wrong. "I know I am using this ignore on purpose - I don't have another option - so why isn't it saying to use expect-error".

The choice is really whether or not you add more words to the message and potentially give people an easy out.

issue.title: Enhancement: [ban-ts-comment] Autofix ts-ignore to ts-expect-error depending on options

labels.name: package: eslint-plugin
labels.description: Issues related to @typescript-eslint/eslint-plugin

labels.name: triage
labels.description: Waiting for maintainers to take a look

labels.name: enhancement: plugin rule option
labels.description: New rule option for an existing eslint-plugin rule

issue.body:
### Before You File a Proposal Please Confirm You Have Done The Following...

- [X] I have [searched for related issues](https://github.com/typescript-eslint/typescript-eslint/issues?q=is%3Aissue+label%3A%22enhancement%3A+plugin+rule+option%22) and found none that match my proposal.
- [X] I have searched the [current rule list](https://typescript-eslint.io/rules/#supported-rules) and found no rules that match my proposal.
- [X] I have [read the FAQ](https://typescript-eslint.io/linting/troubleshooting) and my problem is not listed.

### My proposal is suitable for this project

- [X] I believe my proposal would be useful to the broader TypeScript community (meaning it is not a niche proposal).

### Link to the rule's documentation

https://typescript-eslint.io/rules/ban-ts-comment/

### Description

A fairly common use-case for `ban-ts-comment` is to ban @ts-ignore in favor of @ts-expect-error.

However, if developers are unfamiliar with @ts-expect-error, the error message doesn't help them find out about it.

![](https://github.com/typescript-eslint/typescript-eslint/assets/1782266/b94c3cf9-2bb5-4ae2-a8bd-cb9e8a09f3f5)

The error message should recommend switching, and an autofix should be provided. If @ts-expect-error is also banned, the above original error message can be used instead.

I think it would be useful to autofix even if the rule is configured to require descriptions, as it still saves keystrokes. I don't know if autofixes are allowed to adjust code into a "fail" state however.

### Fail

```typescript
// @ts-ignore
```


### Pass

```typescript
// @ts-expect-error
// ^autofix
```


### Additional Info

_No response_

comment.body: I'm +1 on improving the error message to potentially include `@ts-expect-error`, but autofix feels useless, partly because, as you mentioned, it may produce incorrect code, and partly because it doesn't change anything in practice otherwise—an unreasonably suppressed error stays suppressed. Maybe an editor suggestion fixer would help, though.

issue.title: Repo: Consider reworking our package.json typescript resolution

labels.name: triage
labels.description: Waiting for maintainers to take a look

labels.name: repo maintenance
labels.description: things to do with maintenance of the repo, and not with code/docs

issue.body:
### Suggestion

Forwarding @octogonz's https://github.com/microsoft/rushstack/issues/4404#issuecomment-1779745754 here (thanks again!):

> In fact, looking at your branch, I think the whole problem is that your yarn resolutions are producing an incorrect installation of API Extractor:
> ...
> your project has a wrong installation that does not respect the SemVer ranges requested by package.json files. This is most likely caused by the "resolutions" field from the package.json file in your project root folder. In trying to override some versions, those overrides are overreaching and breaking the functionality of dependencies. If you fix that problem, you can use the current API Extractor without any changes.

This is not an area I've looked into deeply, so just posting for the tracker.

comment.body:
The reason we use resolutions is exactly to solve the issue of multiple versions of TS being installed. Early on we ran into multiple issues due to having multiple versions within tests. Because we rely on TS internals it's a big issue for us to have multiple versions!

It has worked fine for the life of the project because the intersection of "dependencies that depend on TS internals" and "TS breaking api changes" has been tiny - this is the first instance of a breakage due to the resolution, I believe.

issue.title: Bug: [prefer-nullish-coalescing] unexpected fails on condition with generics variable which can be `null` or `undefined`

labels.name: bug
labels.description: Something isn't working

labels.name: package: eslint-plugin
labels.description: Issues related to @typescript-eslint/eslint-plugin

labels.name: triage
labels.description: Waiting for maintainers to take a look

issue.title: Repo: Consider reworking our package.json typescript resolution

labels.name: triage
labels.description: Waiting for maintainers to take a look

labels.name: repo maintenance
labels.description: things to do with maintenance of the repo, and not with code/docs

issue.body:
### Suggestion

Forwarding @octogonz's https://github.com/microsoft/rushstack/issues/4404#issuecomment-1779745754 here (thanks again!):

> In fact, looking at your branch, I think the whole problem is that your yarn resolutions are producing an incorrect installation of API Extractor:
> ...
> your project has a wrong installation that does not respect the SemVer ranges requested by package.json files. This is most likely caused by the "resolutions" field from the package.json file in your project root folder. In trying to override some versions, those overrides are overreaching and breaking the functionality of dependencies. If you fix that problem, you can use the current API Extractor without any changes.

This is not an area I've looked into deeply, so just posting for the tracker.

comment.body:
A quick workaround could simply be:

```js
  "resolutions": {
    . . .
    "@microsoft/api-extractor/typescript": "~5.0.3",
    "typescript": "patch:typescript@npm%3A5.3.0-beta#./.yarn/patches/typescript-npm-5.3.0-beta-33b1e90865.patch"
  },
  ```
  
As far as I know Yarn does not support more expressive rewriting such as [.pnpmfile.cjs](https://pnpm.io/pnpmfile), so you would need to manually adjust the `"~5.0.3"` string whenever `@microsoft/api-extractor` gets upgraded.

It's also worth mentioning: If any of these aggressive `"resolutions"` rules influence the versioning of dependencies of your published packages (any direct OR indirect versions, but not `'devDependencies`), then the versions being used during development may be different from what real users would encounter when they install the shipped NPM.  This can cause bugs to be overlooked during development.

issue.title: Bug: [naming-convention] Default `import` config clashes with common npm import patterns (PascalCase and other-cased imports)

labels.name: bug
labels.description: Something isn't working

labels.name: package: eslint-plugin
labels.description: Issues related to @typescript-eslint/eslint-plugin

labels.name: accepting prs
labels.description: Go ahead, send a pull request that resolves this issue

pull_request.title: fix(eslint-plugin): [naming-convention] allow PascalCase for imports
pull_request.body:
## PR Checklist

- [x] Addresses an existing open issue: fixes #7838
- [x] That issue was marked as [accepting prs](https://github.com/typescript-eslint/typescript-eslint/issues?q=is%3Aopen+is%3Aissue+label%3A%22accepting+prs%22)
- [x] Steps in [Contributing](https://typescript-eslint.io/contributing) were taken

## Overview

Adds `'PascalCase'` alongside `'camelCase'` to the allowed formats for imports. This should allow the majority of community standards, such as `import * as React from "react"`.

Funny that out of the >15,000 (!) generated unit tests for this rule, none were impacted by this change to defaults.

issue.title: Bug: [prefer-nullish-coalescing] unexpected fails on condition with generics variable which can be `null` or `undefined`

labels.name: bug
labels.description: Something isn't working

labels.name: package: eslint-plugin
labels.description: Issues related to @typescript-eslint/eslint-plugin

labels.name: triage
labels.description: Waiting for maintainers to take a look

comment.body:
In the most technical sense - yes, you are correct - `T` could be `null`, or it could be `U | null`.

It does seem pretty odd to me that any code written in this manner would be making an intentional and clear distinction between `null` and `undefined`. It would certainly be a niche edge-case.

Can you provide a little more context behind the code? Does the distinction matter?

issue.title: Bug: [prefer-nullish-coalescing] unexpected fails on condition with generics variable which can be `null` or `undefined`

labels.name: bug
labels.description: Something isn't working

labels.name: package: eslint-plugin
labels.description: Issues related to @typescript-eslint/eslint-plugin

labels.name: triage
labels.description: Waiting for maintainers to take a look

comment.body:
Ah sorry - what I mean to say is:

1. Each of the entries in the `invalid` and `valid` is its own "unit test"
2. In theory, we like having each unit test check for a specific behavior
3. The added code is testing a newly added behavior
4. Therefore, the added code should be added in a new unit test (new entries in the `invalid` or `valid` arrays)

The existing code in our repo doesn't always respect the one-behavior-per-unit-test preference... but new code should ideally.

Does that make sense?

pull_request.title: fix: issue #7763, allowBitwiseExpressions now allows self-referential enums
pull_request.body:
<!--
👋 Hi, thanks for sending a PR to typescript-eslint! 💖
Please fill out all fields below and make sure each item is true and [x] checked.
Otherwise we may not be able to review your PR.
-->

## PR Checklist

- [x] Addresses an existing open issue: fixes #7763
- [x] That issue was marked as [accepting prs](https://github.com/typescript-eslint/typescript-eslint/issues?q=is%3Aopen+is%3Aissue+label%3A%22accepting+prs%22)
- [x] Steps in [Contributing](https://typescript-eslint.io/contributing) were taken

## Overview

Allows enums with binary bitwise expressions if both operands are literals or reference members of own enum
